sub_topic: Solving nonlinear equations using Newton-Raphson method
message_1: Consider the equation f(x) = x^3 - 2x - 5. Using the Newton-Raphson method, find the root of the equation accurate to 4 decimal places, starting with an initial guess of x0 = 2.
message_2:
To use the Newton-Raphson method, we first need to find the derivative of the function f(x) = x^3 - 2x - 5. The derivative, f'(x), is:

f'(x) = 3x^2 - 2

Now, we will apply the Newton-Raphson formula iteratively until we reach the desired accuracy of 4 decimal places. The formula is:

x1 = x0 - f(x0) / f'(x0)

We start with the initial guess x0 = 2:

1st iteration:
x1 = 2 - (2^3 - 2*2 - 5) / (3*(2^2) - 2)
x1 = 2 - (8 - 4 - 5) / (12 - 2)
x1 = 2 - (-1) / 10
x1 = 2.1

2nd iteration:
x2 = 2.1 - (2.1^3 - 2*2.1 - 5) / (3*(2.1^2) - 2)
x2 ≈ 2.0946

3rd iteration:
x3 = 2.0946 - (2.0946^3 - 2*2.0946 - 5) / (3*(2.0946^2) - 2)
x3 ≈ 2.094551

Since the difference between x2 and x3 is less than 0.0001, we can stop here. The root of the equation f(x) = x^3 - 2x - 5, accurate to 4 decimal places, is approximately x ≈ 2.0946.
